title: 105_s620
content: The "Women's Investment and Savings Equity Act of 1997" allows individuals to make deductible IRA contributions without considering their spouse's participation in a pension plan. Additionally, individuals can contribute during periods of maternity or paternity leave. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on maternity or paternity leave to make additional contributions to their plans, impacting the qualification of trusts and plans under various sections of the code. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under the plan, impacting contribution limits under various sections of the code. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under the plan, impacting contribution limits under various sections of the code such as section 402(g), 402(h), 403(b), 404(a), 404(h), 408, 415, or 457. Contributions are subject to limitations and must comply with rules prescribed by the Secretary for the year they relate to. The plan must not fail to meet the requirements of section. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under the plan without requiring matching contributions from the employer. Matching contributions made during a year must meet the requirements of section 401(a)(4) separately. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under the plan without requiring matching contributions from the employer. The amount of any matching contribution made during a year must not exceed the maximum amount that could have been made under the plan if the elective deferral had been made during the eligible leave period. The plan must specify the amount and timing of elective deferrals permitted for employees during eligible maternity or paternity leave. Employees on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals under the plan, with adjustments made for deferrals actually made during the leave period. Employees on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make elective deferrals within 3 years after the leave ends. Matching contributions must be made by the employer's tax return due date. Eligible leave is defined in the subsection. Eligible maternity or paternity leave allows individuals to be absent from work for reasons such as pregnancy, childbirth, adoption, or caring for a child after birth or placement, for a maximum period of 12 weeks. The term 'elective deferral' includes after-tax employee contributions. 'Plan' encompasses arrangements under section 408(k) or (p). Certain retroactive adjustments are not required for this subchapter and subchapter E. The rules of subsection (u)(3) apply for this subchapter and subchapter E. Loan repayment suspensions are allowed for eligible maternity and paternity leave under subsection (u)(4). Effective starting December 31, 1997. SEC. 4. Catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan. Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan. This amendment affects various types of plans and arrangements, requiring them to permit eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals. The amendment to Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code allows catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan. Plans and arrangements must permit eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals in certified catchup years. The amount of additional deferrals allowed is limited. The amendment to Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code allows catchup contributions for eligible participants in certified catchup years. The additional deferrals allowed are limited to the lesser of the participant's elective deferrals under the plan or 120 percent of the applicable dollar limitation for the calendar year. The amendment to Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code allows catchup contributions for eligible participants in certified catchup years. Contributions to a plan under this section are not subject to certain limitations for the year they are made. The amendment allows catch-up contributions in certified catch-up years without limitations under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment allows catch-up contributions in certified catch-up years without limitations under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including provisions related to matching contributions under section 401(a)(4). The amendment permits additional elective deferrals in certified catch-up years, with a maximum contribution limit based on the plan's terms. Participants must certify their eligibility and the year as a catch-up year to the plan administrator. An eligible participant can certify one or more catch-up years, limited to a total not exceeding the difference between the number of years before the current year and the years previously certified. Plans are not held responsible for certification failures. An eligible participant can certify catch-up years, limited to the difference between previous certifications and the current year. Plans are not responsible for certification failures unless the administrator knew or should have known about the incorrect certification. The subsection defines terms like elective deferral and plan, including arrangements under section 408(k) or (p). The term 'plan' includes arrangements under section 408(k) or (p), and certain retroactive adjustments are not required. The amendment applies to contributions in taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
